newsitem.title: UK: UK water watchdog's bite lacks teeth, market says.
newsitem.headline: UK water watchdog's bite lacks teeth, market says.

text.p: Britain's water industry regulator fired a warning shot at sector "fatcats" on Thursday, slamming excessive dividends and threatening price cuts.
But OFWAT's broadside fell far short of what the market had feared and relieved investors pumped funds into the sector's shares, pushing some leading companies up over four percent.

OFWAT's head Ian Byatt told a news conference he was considering a one-off price cut at his next industry review due in 1999 and that companies must rethink what he called their "unsustainable" dividend payouts.
"The water companies are paying dividends which are growing faster than profits...This is unwise. It will have to stop," Byatt said.
Byatt suggested annual dividends should rise by between nought and two percent plus inflation and said companies should "examine their consciences".

Britain's newly-privatised water companies have been savaged for pumping funds into hefty dividend payouts, sometimes rising by around 20 percent, while complaints about water stoppages and leaks have soared.
The newly-elected Labour government has seized on that public outrage and has threatened a windfall tax on privatised companies' profits and tougher regulation.
But details have been sketchy and the spectre of the tax -- once speculated to be as high as 10 billion pounds ($16.6 billion) but now closer to half that -- has dwindled in investors' minds.
Market players were given a further fillip by Byatt sidestepping the critical issue of the levy, saying only it was a matter for Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown and his budget on July 2.

"People were looking at whether Byatt would do anything on dividends. The answer is, long on words, short on action. And the windfall tax has been kicked into touch," Nigel Hawkins, analyst at Yamaichi in London, said.

"The key thing is there are various suggestions in the press that the windfall tax may be only three billion pounds. And if British Telecommunications Plc have to pay a central chunk of that, then it is good news for water and electricity," Hawkins said.
Among leading shares, Anglian Water Plc gained 28-1/2p to 677p and Thames Water Plc, lambasted for one of the country's worst records on leaks, was up 22p at 675p.

Byatt has been a staunch critic of water firms' dividend increases, arguing that hefty payouts could undermine urgently-needed investment programmes. He said water quality would form a major pillar of the next review.
Byatt said he was considering a new approach to funding to ensure companies could only raise revenue from customers to meet obligations on quality after they had delivered them.
"At the moment, customers are paying for such improvements while the work is underway, contrary to normal commercial practice," Byatt said.
He said OFWAT was examining ways to ensure consumers were more conscious about saving water, possibly through companies' tariff structures.
